author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Cuts Rates, but Projects Fewer Reductions Next Year
description: Federal Reserve officials projected just two rate cuts in 2025, and they made it clear that future reductions would hinge on inflation progress.
content: Federal Reserve officials made their third and final rate cut of 2024 at their meeting on Wednesday. They also forecast two fewer rate reductions in 2025 than they had previously expected, as inflation lingers and the economy holds up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: White House Pushes to Find American Journalist Abducted in Syria
description: U.S. officials have given the rebel group in control of Damascus a list of former members of the Assad government who could have information about Austin Tice.
content: The White House has given the rebel group that toppled the Syrian government a list of former officials who might have knowledge about Austin Tice, an American journalist who was abducted in Damascus in 2012.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Miami Broker Turns Himself In to Face Sexual Battery Charge
description: Ohad Fisherman is accused of participating in an alleged sexual assault in 2016 alongside Oren and Alon Alexander.
content: Ohad Fisherman, who is accused along with the real estate agent Oren Alexander and his twin brother, Alon Alexander, of participating in an alleged sexual assault in 2016, surrendered to authorities in Miami on Wednesday. A judge said she would release Mr. Fisherman on bond after his family secured funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Milton Esterow
title: The U.S. Has No Special Panel for Nazi-Loot Claims. Could That Change?
description: Several European countries have restitution commissions that decide claims regarding art lost in the Holocaust. Some people think there should be a U.S. panel too.
content: The Washington Principles, adopted by the United States and 43 other countries in 1998, guide nations on how to handle claims for Nazi-looted art and recommend that countries create alternative dispute resolution processes, separate from their courts, to settle cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: 500 Drones Over Central Park? Nothing to Worry About.
description: Both Central and Prospect Parks are planning drone shows on New Year’s Eve, after canceling their usual fireworks displays.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll get details on drone shows in Central Park and Prospect Park that are planned for New Year’s Eve. We’ll also find out why a judge upheld a bribery charge that Mayor Eric Adams is facing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: A Russian general was killed yesterday by a bomb on a Moscow street. Ukraine claimed responsibility for what appears to be one of the most brazen assassinations since Russia’s full-scale invasion nearly three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Wednesday Briefing: Russia Arrests a Suspected Assassin
description: Plus, the big stories of 2024 through our photographers’ eyes.
content: The Russian authorities said yesterday that they had detained a suspect in the killing of a senior military officer, Lt. Gen. Igor Kirillov. The officer, who died in a bombing on Tuesday, was the target of the most prominent political assassination in Russia since the invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Can Anyone Make Sense of Luigi Mangione? Maybe His Favorite Writer.
description: How to make sense of the UnitedHealthcare C.E.O. shooting
content: Almost immediately after Luigi Mangione was arrested last week in connection with the killing of Brian Thompson, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare, you could go pretty deep into the rabbit hole of Mangione’s particular internet. At the top of his X feed, I noticed a reference to the work of Tim Urban, the popular blogger, essayist and author of the website Wait but Why and a 2023 book dilating on the problems of uncivil political discourse, called “What’s Our Problem?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: How to Read the Fed’s Projections Like a Pro
description: The Federal Reserve will release fresh economic estimates on Wednesday. Here’s how to read the outlook for 2025 and beyond.
content: Federal Reserve officials are scheduled to release a fresh set of economic projections alongside their rate decision on Wednesday, forecasts that will offer a fresh glimpse of just how much and how quickly central bankers expect interest rates to come down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French, Jonathan Rauch and Vishakha Darbha
title: What if Our Democracy Can’t Survive Without Christianity?
description: An atheist helps David French understand how religion supports America’s political ideals.
content: The New York Times Opinion columnist David French, a lifelong evangelical, speaks to Jonathan Rauch, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and an atheist, about the role of Christianity in redeeming and supporting American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Investigation of Police ‘Courtesy Cards’ Finds a 2-Tiered System of Justice
description: Videos released by a New Jersey government watchdog have pierced a veil of secrecy around cards that can be used to avoid traffic tickets.
content: The credit-card-size documents are known by many names: police courtesy cards, gold cards or family cards. They are distributed by law enforcement officers and their unions to a favored few and are flashed by drivers hoping for leniency when stopped for traffic violations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Bonisteel
title: The Food Stories We Couldn’t Put Down in 2024
description: From restaurant lists to indispensable cooking tips, these are our most read articles of the year.
content: Election. Eclipse. Eras Tour. As the new year approaches, the news moments of 2024 flash like the old ticker in Times Square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: These Men Can’t Get Enough Leather
description: A younger generation discovers the appeal of wearing skins.
content: In March, Brandon Mahler took a pair of thrifted leather pants and spliced them into shorts. Holding the results, Mr. Mahler, a fashion consultant in New York, had to acknowledge that he’d crossed the line of sartorial sanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Education Dept. Reverses Itself and Reopens Two Loan Repayment Plans
description: The department had been trying to phase out the two plans in favor of a more generous new one that has been tied up by litigation since this summer.
content: The Education Department reopened enrollment on Friday in two student loan repayment plans it had sought to replace, allowing borrowers to transfer out of the alternative program it had proposed, which has been frozen by litigation since July.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trump Takes Credit for New Border Security Plan Outlined by Canada
description: After Canada unveiled its plan to secure the border with the United States, Mr. Trump’s transition team attributed the action to the president elect.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday took credit for a new border security plan — that was announced by Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senate Clears Defense Bill Denying Transgender Care to Minors
description: The annual defense bill directing $895 billion toward the Pentagon and other military programs would deny transgender health coverage to minors. It now heads to President Biden’s desk.
content: The Senate on Wednesday gave final approval to a defense policy bill directing $895 billion toward the Pentagon and other military activities, moving over the objections of some Democrats who opposed a provision added late in the negotiations that would deny coverage for transgender health procedures for minors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and John Ismay
title: China’s Nuclear Buildup Is on Track Despite Graft Scandals, Pentagon Says
description: Corruption investigations may have shaken Beijing’s confidence in top commanders, but China’s military expansion hasn’t slowed, a report found.
content: China’s nuclear arsenal and other elements of its armed forces have grown robustly despite anticorruption investigations that have shaken the People’s Liberation Army at its highest levels, the Pentagon said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Catherine Porter, Shannon Lin, Eric Krupke, Rob Szypko, Olivia Natt, Lexie Diao, Michael Benoist, Sophia Lanman, Pat McCusker, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: France’s Horrifying Rape Trial Has a Feminist Hero
description: Gisèle Pelicot’s former husband and 50 other men are accused of raping her. Her poise and courage have made her an icon.
content: Warning: This episode contains graphic descriptions of sexual violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Who Is Friedrich Merz, a Leading Candidate to Be Germany’s Next Chancellor?
description: If polls are correct, Olaf Scholz’s successor could be the 69-year-old leader of the Christian Democratic Union. He is offering to get the German economic engine humming again.
content: The man most likely to replace Olaf Scholz as chancellor of Germany after the coalition government fell on Monday earned his fortune working in the private sector before returning to politics at 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: Don’t Call It a Bachelor Pad. TikTok Says It’s a ‘Boy Apartment.’
description: Men with meticulously curated homes are going viral on TikTok, changing the way people think about male living habits.
content: On a recent fall morning, Ben Taylor Lebowitz neatly made his bed, placing each throw pillow in its rightful place; threw on a sweater and hat; lit a eucalyptus-scented candle; and hit the “espresso" button on his sleek coffee maker. Mr. Lebowitz, 35, the founder of a pet portrait company, was filming a video of his morning routine for his hundreds of thousands of followers on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Central Bankers Around the Globe Gird Themselves for Another Trump Term
description: Central bankers are alert to the risk that global trade tensions will make managing inflation more challenging.
content: Just as central bankers around the world were growing more confident that inflation was coming back under control and growth stabilizing, a new economic threat looms: potentially hefty tariffs imposed by President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Change With the Times
description: Jeffrey Martinovic and Will Nediger up the ante.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Aghast at a Move to Revoke the Polio Vaccine
description: Readers write about the polio vaccine and the dread of the disease in the past. Also: Reducing crime; the Unabomber’s victims; health insurances woes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Drug Charges Against Sean Combs Associate Are Dropped in Florida
description: The charges against Brendan Paul, a former Syracuse University basketball player who was arrested amid raids on Mr. Combs’s homes, were dropped after he completed a diversion program.
content: An associate of Sean Combs who was arrested on drug possession charges in March amid the federal raids on Mr. Combs’s homes has had the case against him dropped after he completed a diversion program, his lawyer announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Ivy League Agrees to Let Football Teams Compete in the Postseason Next Year
description: The conference’s eight schools will be able to participate in the Football Championship Subdivision’s 24-team playoff.
content: Among the tens of thousands of college athletes who compete for an N.C.A.A. championship, there is one subset who never get the chance: Ivy League football players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: ‘Murder Hornet’ Has Been Eradicated From the U.S., Officials Say
description: The hornet was discovered in a corner of Washington State. Five years later, a massive mobilization has eliminated the invasive species, at least for now.
content: The hunt for the “murder hornet” in the northwest corner of Washington State began like a criminal investigation, with bee carcasses creating a crime scene and the public being asked to send tips about the potential culprit’s whereabouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 557
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Dec. 19, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Man Who Ran Secret Police Office in New York Admits He Was Chinese Agent
description: Chen Jinping used the office in Lower Manhattan to quash dissent against the Chinese government. The Justice Department is fighting Beijing’s efforts to wield its influence secretly.
content: A man pleaded guilty in federal court in Brooklyn on Wednesday to charges that he had worked as an unauthorized agent of the Chinese government, running a police outpost in Lower Manhattan as part of an effort to quash criticism of Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Miller
title: How the Right Claimed ‘Crunchy’
description: Once, eating whole foods and avoiding toxins was associated with a lefty worldview. Now, being a “crunchy mom” is more often about “health freedom.”
content: Not to brag, but I have stellar “crunchy” bona fides. I was raised on wheat bread, limited television and camping vacations, and at 17 went off to Oberlin College, that notorious incubator of crunchy achievers. I am deeply familiar with old-school crunchy in all of its hues: the lumpy hand-knit sweaters, the unkempt hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis and Neal E. Boudette
title: Honda and Nissan Are in Talks to Deepen Ties and Possibly Merge
description: The merger talks between Japan’s second- and third-largest automakers highlight the intense upheaval within the world’s auto industry.
content: Honda Motor and Nissan Motor, Japan’s second- and third-largest automakers, are discussing ways to deepen their ties, including the possibility of a merger that could fundamentally restructure Japan’s car industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: E.P.A. Allows California to Ban Sales of New Gas-Powered Cars by 2035
description: The Trump administration is expected to revoke the program, setting up a legal clash between the state and federal government.
content: The Biden administration on Wednesday granted California and 11 other states permission to ban the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035, one of the most ambitious climate policies in the United States and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: The Rev. James Callan, Renegade Catholic Priest, Dies at 77
description: He was excommunicated in 1999 after allowing women to celebrate Mass, blessing same-sex unions and offering communion to non-Catholics.
content: The Rev. James B. Callan, a renegade priest who was excommunicated in 1999 after he offered holy communion to non-Catholics, allowed women to celebrate Mass and blessed same-sex unions — and who then helped establish an independent Catholic church that is thriving a quarter-century later — died on Friday in Rochester, N.Y. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Police Chiefs Were Too Slow to React to Summer Riots, Report Says
description: Police leaders waited too long — three days — to trigger a national mobilization to tackle the anti-immigrant violence that broke out in Britain this year, a report found.
content: A national plan to mobilize British police was triggered three days too late during anti-immigration riots that shook the country this summer, an official report said Wednesday, in part because intelligence assessments didn’t accurately predict the scale of the violence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Photos that Defined 2024
description: The year was made up of extraordinary moments — and Times photographers captured them in extraordinary images.
content: When shots were fired at a campaign rally for Donald Trump on a July evening in Butler, Pa., the veteran New York Times photographer Doug Mills was just a few feet from him. The Secret Service rushed toward Trump. Doug’s heart pounded when he realized what was happening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: Tax Preparer Known as ‘the Magician’ Bilked I.R.S. Out of $145 Million
description: A businessman in the Bronx falsified information on thousands of returns, committing one of the largest tax frauds in Department of Justice history, prosecutors said.
content: A tax preparer in the Bronx spent decades operating a business where he filed returns for thousands of clients, often getting them big refunds. Customers called him “the magician” because it seemed he could make their tax burdens disappear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: How a Forgotten TV Show Forever Changed the Way We Look at Art
description: Weekly from 1956 to ’63, a charismatic painter named Lorser Feitelson filled America’s living rooms with the first televised history of art. We’re still exploring — and trapped in — his world.
content: As the Iron Curtain fell on Eastern Europe and as Joseph McCarthy, a senior Republican senator from Wisconsin, was railing against the U.S. State Department being “infested with communists,” an intimidating group of abstract painters were occupying America’s galleries. In August 1949, the same month Life magazine called Jackson Pollock “the greatest living painter in the United States,” the Michigan Representative George Dondero outlined on the House floor all the ways art history posed a threat to democracy: “Cubism aims to destroy by designed disorder,” he cried. “Expressionism aims to destroy by aping the primitive and insane. Abstractionism aims to destroy by the creation of brainstorms. Surrealism aims to destroy by the denial of reason.” Modern art became a screen onto which Americans could project their fears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Vogel
title: Buy, Donate, Repeat: At 91, Leonard Lauder Has More to Give
description: Picasso paintings. Jasper Johns ale cans. Irving Penn photos. The cosmetics heir created the model for the headline-grabbing donation that museums dream of today.
content: In the 1980s, when major collectors were scooping up paintings by Monet and Matisse, Leonard A. Lauder, the philanthropist and cosmetics heir, was forging his own path with Cubism, collecting Picasso and Braque, its pioneers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Inside Disney’s Decision to Settle a Trump Defamation Suit
description: Talks started and finished on the same day, after Disney decided that fighting the lawsuit could potentially hurt the company and protections for the press.
content: When Disney reached a settlement last week with President-elect Donald J. Trump in his defamation case against ABC News, it led to accusations that the company had caved to him. Media law experts predicted the move would embolden Mr. Trump to file other lawsuits that could test the limits of the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Borrell
title: He Built a Wellness Empire While Adventuring With Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
description: Dr. Mark Hyman, a “functional medicine” proponent and longtime friend of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., is finding powerful allies in his bid to treat disease with blood tests and supplements.
content: Dr. Mark Hyman didn’t hesitate before accepting an invitation, 14 years ago, to a weeklong white-water rafting trip with Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Hopes for a New Syria Take Flight
description: A Syrian Air flight from Damascus landed in Aleppo on Wednesday, as the transitional government tries to demonstrate its ability to run the war-shattered country.
content: Shortly before the first domestic flight since Bashar al-Assad’s fall landed at Aleppo International Airport late Wednesday morning, the final preparations were still being made. Workers rushed to remove about a dozen empty ammunition boxes, gas masks and helmets from a grassy patch next to the runway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: House Republicans Call for Liz Cheney to Be Investigated Over Jan. 6 Committee Role
description: Ms. Cheney defended her work on the select committee in a detailed statement, and called the report “a malicious and cowardly assault on the truth.”
content: House Republicans on Tuesday said their one-time colleague, former Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, should face a criminal investigation for her role on the select committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Questions Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s Workout Fashion
description: Reports said Kennedy exercised at a gym in jeans and hiking boots. “If you think that’s weird, wait until you hear every single other thing about him,” Meyers said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: An American Curator Takes the Helm at Crisis-Hit Documenta
description: Naomi Beckwith, who holds a leadership role at the Guggenheim Museum in New York, said she would make navigating crises a central theme of her exhibition.
content: Documenta, the prestigious German contemporary art exhibition held twice a decade, announced on Wednesday that Naomi Beckwith, the deputy director and chief curator at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York, would oversee the next edition in 2027.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: A Baby Capybara’s Rise to Fame Is a Perfect End to 2024
description: Like this year’s other viral baby animals, Tupi was quickly embraced on social media. An hour later, the San Antonio Zoo distanced itself from a memecoin named after him.
content: As the largest rodents in the world, most capybaras spend their days munching on grass and water plants in dense vegetation around bodies of water. At a zoo in Texas, however, one capybara has stepped up as the latest in a series of baby animals to capture the internet’s attention this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Democrats, Don’t Forget the Atheists
description: Galvanize these voters without alienating of party members of faith would be pretty easy.
content: Sometimes it feels like white Christians are the only religious voting bloc with true sway in America. Conservative evangelicals in particular have a great deal of power in the Republican Party, thanks to their tight embrace of Donald Trump. I often hear people talk about how Democrats can win back some white Christian support, as if that should be the party’s priority in the coming years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisy Fried
title: The History of Poetry, From the Bronze Age to A.I., in a Single Poem
description: With “Context Collapse,” Ryan Ruby aims to explain poetry’s origins and its waves of innovation all the way to the present.
content: Here’s a book-length poem about poetic innovation, about the ways, over millenniums, that poets and audiences have conceived of each other, and about how poems get delivered from producer to consumer — but wait! Ryan Ruby’s “Context Collapse” is all of that, yes, but it’s also fun. And irritating, fascinating, poignant, a folly, a lark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Steven Erlanger
title: Zelensky Meets With European Leaders to Discuss Ukraine’s Future
description: As Donald J. Trump prepares to take office in the United States, President Volodymyr Zelensky attended a meeting hosted by the NATO chief to plot the path forward in the war with Russia.
content: Mark Rutte, the head of NATO, met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and other European leaders at Mr. Rutte’s residence in Brussels on Wednesday to discuss the deteriorating situation in the war with Russia and how Europe can offer more support to Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Google Street View Captures a Man Loading a Bag Into a Trunk. Arrests Follow.
description: The image, from northern Spain, showed a man with a white bag in the trunk of a car. The National Police said it helped them solve a missing-person case.
content: It was a routine image picked up by Google Street View: a man loading a white bag into the trunk of a car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Didi,’ ‘Janet Planet’ and the Year’s Great Under-the-Radar Streaming Films
description: Here are just a few of the year’s finest indies, documentaries and international selections, available to stream at this very minute.
content: In what has become an annual tradition, this month’s guide to the under-the-radar titles of your subscription services spotlights films from this calendar year — movies that may turn up on the year-end lists of your favorite critics, or as nominations and winners during awards season. Here are just a few of the year’s finest indies, documentaries and international selections, available to stream at this very minute:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Woman Who Faced Racism When Buying a Home Speaks Out Against Bias
description: Raven Baxter will be the face of a national campaign to prevent housing discrimination, supported by a grant from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.
content: Dr. Raven Baxter, who was astonished earlier this year when a white homeowner tried to deny her the right to buy a condo, will be the face of a new national campaign aimed at combating housing discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $300,000 Homes in Kansas, Virginia and New Jersey
description: A Queen Anne Revival in Leavenworth, a ranch house in Richmond, and a rowhouse in Trenton.
content: This three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bathroom house near the center of town is within a 10-minute walk of the Leavenworth Historical Society and a public library. Leavenworth Landing Park, on the Missouri River, is a five-minute drive, as are an Irish pub, a kitschy railroad-themed restaurant and the C.W. Parker Carousel Museum,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendell Potter
title: I Was a Health Insurance Executive. What I Saw Made Me Quit.
description: Shareholders, not patient outcomes, tend to drive decisions at health insurance companies.
content: I left my job as a health insurance executive at Cigna after a crisis of conscience. It began in 2005, during a meeting convened by the chief executive to brief department heads on the company’s latest strategy: “consumerism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The New Politics
description: At the DealBook Summit, nine prominent political figures, advisers and journalists debated what drove Trump’s victory and what it means for politics going forward. Here’s what they said.
content: In the month since President-elect Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election, there has been much debate over what led to his clear but narrow victory. At a task force session at the DealBook Summit, The Times’s senior political correspondent Maggie Haberman moderated a thoughtful, nuanced and sometimes contentious debate among political figures, advisers and journalists about what happened. Heres what they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Inside a Huge Spending Deal: Disaster Money, a Football Stadium and More
description: The mammoth year-end federal funding measure congressional leaders agreed on does far more than just keep the government running. It is stuffed with all manner of policy and other changes.
content: The stopgap spending bill congressional leaders agreed on this week began as a simple funding measure to keep government funds flowing past a Friday night deadline and into early next year, long after House Republicans elect a speaker and President-elect Donald J. Trump is sworn in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Biden Administration Running Out of Time to Send Allocated Aid to Ukraine
description: Senior officials discussed U.S. plans to announce additional support for Ukraine, and spoke about casualties among North Korean troops sent to help Russia.
content: The Biden administration is unlikely to spend all of the remaining $5.6 billion that Congress has allocated to send weapons and other military help to Ukraine, a senior Defense Department official said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Christina Djossa, Amy Pearl, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Efim Shapiro, Dan Powell and Marion Lozano
title: Your Worst Dates Ever: With Joel Kim Booster
description: The actor and host of the podcast “Bad Dates” brings a fresh perspective to your worst dates.
content: It felt as if the dating world hit a breaking point this year. With news headlines like “Is Dating a Total Nightmare for You Right Now?” and “Why the Young and the Single Can’t Commit to Dating Apps” appearing frequently, it became clear that there was a lot of pent up frustration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: 2 Endangered Whales Found Entangled in Fishing Gear, With 1 Likely to Die
description: The North Atlantic right whales, which were seen off the coast of Massachusetts, are one of the most endangered large whale species.
content: Two endangered whales have been found entangled in fishing gear off the coast of Massachusetts, and one of them is likely to die from his injuries, according to the federal agency that monitors the oceans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Pentagon Repatriates Malaysian Prisoners Who Pleaded Guilty to War Crimes
description: The prisoners were airlifted from Guantánamo Bay in a secret operation nearly a year after they admitted to serving as foot soldiers for the accused Indonesian terrorist leader Hambali.
content: The Pentagon said on Wednesday that it had repatriated two Malaysian men from its prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, who admitted to committing war crimes for an affiliate of Al Qaeda that carried out a deadly bombing in Bali, Indonesia, in 2002.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Senators Call for Investigation of Medicaid Work Requirement Program
description: A group of Democratic lawmakers accused Georgia Pathways to Coverage, the only Medicaid work requirement program in the country, of spending little of its funding on health benefits.
content: A group of Democratic senators said on Wednesday that they had called for a federal watchdog investigation into a controversial Medicaid work requirement program in Georgia, accusing its administrators of churning through tens of millions of dollars in funding while enrolling a fraction of the low-income residents estimated to be eligible for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Social Media Trends
description: What are the best and worst you’ve seen this year?
content: Have you seen people on TikTok putting beef on their faces? The Times reports:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber
title: What Fed Rate Moves Mean for Your Finances
description: Here’s how the central bank’s interest rate moves influence car loans, credit cards, mortgages, savings and student loans.
content: The Federal Reserve is expected to lower its key rate by another quarter point on Wednesday, marking its third consecutive cut since September. In total, rates will have dropped by a full percentage point since then.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Under Pressure, Hyundai Supplier Ends Alabama Prison Labor Contract
description: The supplier fired dozens of prisoners after some of them said they felt they had no choice but to take those jobs.
content: After facing public scrutiny for the use of prison labor, a supplier to the South Korean automaker Hyundai said it had dismissed dozens of incarcerated men it had employed through the Alabama Department of Corrections and ended its inmate labor contract with the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Maya C. Miller
title: Congressional Leaders Unveil Short-Term Spending Bill Tied to Disaster Aid
description: What started out as a simple stopgap measure to avert a shutdown for a few months became a magnet for more than $100 billion in emergency disaster and farm aid, plus a host of unrelated policy measures.
content: Congressional leaders on Tuesday unveiled legislation that would keep government funding flowing through the middle of March and provide nearly $100 billion in aid for communities ravaged by hurricanes and other disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Who Will Be New Jersey’s Next Governor? It’s Wide Open.
description: At least 10 candidates are vying for attention, including two members of Congress, two mayors, a far-right radio host and a former state senator known as “Ed the Trucker.”
content: With no incumbent in the race, next year’s contest to replace Philip D. Murphy as governor of New Jersey was never going to be dull.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Trump Picks Herschel Walker to Be Ambassador to the Bahamas
description: The president-elect tapped the former football star for the job two years after a failed run for a Senate seat in Georgia.
content: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Donald Trump and the presidential transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: ‘Skibidi Toilet’ Has Come to Fortnite. What the Heck Is It?
description: In the survival battle video game with 110 million monthly players, you can now wear a skibidi toilet as a backpack. Here is a breakdown of what in the world that means.
content: Do you like video games? Have you ever wanted to control Indiana Jones as he faces off against a sentient banana, or to lay siege to Eminem’s underground lair? Then, dear player, Fortnite is up your alley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: The Making and Remaking of ‘Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas’
description: Eighty years after its release, the sentimental holiday standard continues to enchant listeners and inspire the musicians who take it on.
content: Audiences who filed into movie theaters in late 1944 to see the musical “Meet Me in St. Louis” were treated to soon-to-be standards sung by Judy Garland, including “The Trolley Song” and “The Boy Next Door.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: The Dark Mystery of France’s Most Notorious Sexual Predator
description: For over three months, judges and lawyers have tried to grasp the true nature of Dominique Pelicot, who said he had invited dozens of strangers to join him in raping his drugged wife.
content: Dominique Pelicot is France’s most infamous predator. He admits that he surreptitiously drugged his wife for almost a decade so that he could rape her, and that he invited dozens of strangers he met online to violate her limp, snoring body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Two Dead in Small Plane Crash in Hawaii
description: The plane, which was reportedly on a training flight with a cargo carrier, could be seen veering away from a highway before it crashed into a vacant building.
content: A small plane crash killed two people on Tuesday near the Daniel K. Inouye International Airport in Honolulu, Hawaii, officials said, after a training flight for a local cargo carrier crashed shortly after takeoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: What to Know About the Charges Against Luigi Mangione
description: The man the authorities say killed UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive is accused of crimes in Pennsylvania and New York, including first-degree murder, which is a terrorism charge.
content: Luigi Mangione, the man arrested in the Dec. 4 killing of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive, has been charged with crimes in both New York and Pennsylvania, including a terrorism count.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Rayful Edmond, Drug Lord Who Stoked D.C.’s Crack Cocaine Epidemic, Dies at 60
description: He rose to prominence in the 1980s, spending lavishly and befriending athletes, as the city was wracked by murders tied to the drug trade. He later became an informant.
content: Rayful Edmond, a drug kingpin who stoked a crack cocaine epidemic in Washington, D.C., in the 1980s and later cooperated with prosecutors to bring down cocaine traffickers years after he was sentenced to life in prison, died on Tuesday in Florida. He was 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: marginalized
description: This word has appeared in 344 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word marginalized has appeared in 344 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 5 in the Turning Points feature “The Big Question: What Is Underrated?”:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida Charges Man Suspected of Trump Assassination Plot
description: As Ryan W. Routh fled the scene, a highway was shut down and a car crash ensued. In charging him with attempted felony murder, the state defied federal prosecutors.
content: Florida officials filed charges on Wednesday against the man accused of trying to assassinate President-elect Donald J. Trump at his West Palm Beach golf course in September, defying federal prosecutors who had asked the state to suspend its investigation while their own moved forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: David Bonderman, Private Equity Pioneer, Is Dead at 82
description: A globe-trotting lawyer turned investor, he helped transform a cottage industry into a colossus with influence on Wall Street and beyond.
content: David Bonderman, a founder of the giant investment firm TPG, who helped transform private equity into a multitrillion-dollar industry that reshaped corporate America, died on Dec. 11. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How Worried Should We Be About Bird Flu?
description: California has declared a state of emergency over the virus. We asked experts how concerned they are.
content: California has declared a state of emergency over the outbreak of bird flu among dairy cows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Which Films Will Be Nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars?
description: You can expect the A-B-C-D-E movies (“Anora,” “The Brutalist,” “Conclave,” “Dune: Part Two” and “Emilia Pérez”). But what will join them?
content: Oscar season kicked into high gear this month, transforming a race that once appeared to be wide-open into something with a little more shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: A Rift in Trump World Over How to Make America Healthier
description: Statements by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Elon Musk tap into a dispute over whether lifestyle changes or drugs are a better way to treat obesity.
content: For Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the activist whom President-elect Donald J. Trump will nominate to serve as the secretary of health and human services, the solution to obesity in America — now at 40 percent of adults — is straightforward: “The first line of response should be lifestyle,” he told Jim Cramer in a Dec. 12 interview on CNBC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Mimi Dwyer
title: F.B.I. Searches Home of L.A. Deputy Mayor Suspected of Bomb Threat Against City Hall
description: The official, Brian Williams, was appointed by the mayor last year to oversee public safety. He was immediately placed on administrative leave, the mayor’s office said.
content: F.B.I. agents searched the home of a Los Angeles deputy mayor this week as part of an investigation into a bomb threat that officials believe he made against City Hall earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: American Kitchens Face an Uncertain Mix: Olive Oil and Tariffs
description: Trump hasn’t said whether he’ll move against imported foods, but the effects on oil producers and consumers are already being debated.
content: Few ingredients are more essential to American cooks today than olive oil. And none is more affected by geopolitics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Neighbor Won’t Stop Praying for Me. What Should I Do?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to navigate religious differences with someone you care for.
content: I have an 85-year-old neighbor who is a sweet friend and caring person. My issue is that she is very religious and I’m not at all. She prays for me and says it in person, texts and emails for even the most minor of situations. I’ve told her my view of religion and that she doesn’t need to pray for me. She said she has to, otherwise she’s not following the Bible. I’m trying to ignore this but it’s really bothering me that she can’t respect my wishes. — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Documentaries Ripped From the Headlines Are Becoming Harder to See
description: Films about Israel and a union drive at Amazon are acclaimed Oscar hopefuls. But they are largely unavailable to American audiences.
content: Several years ago, two Palestinians and two Israelis decided to make a documentary about the Israeli government’s efforts to demolish homes in Masafer Yatta in the southern West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Cade Metz, Theodore Schleifer and Benjamin Weiser
title: Is Elon Musk a National Security Risk?
description: Federal agencies are reviewing whether the tech mogul and ally of Donald Trump complied with disclosure rules meant to protect state secrets.
content: Even before becoming “first buddy” to President-elect Donald Trump, Elon Musk wielded significant influence in government, thanks to SpaceX.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Court Upends a State Takeover of a Troubled Police Force
description: New Jersey’s attorney general, Matthew J. Platkin, seized control of the Paterson Police Department in March 2023. He vowed to appeal a ruling that found he had overstepped his authority.
content: A New Jersey appellate court ruled Wednesday that the state’s attorney general, Matthew J. Platkin, had overstepped his authority when he seized control of the police department in Paterson, the state’s third-largest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Now Is Not the Time for Surrender
description: What do Democrats need to do? Act like an opposition party.
content: Democrats may be in the minority, but they are not yet an opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘What Could Those Two Be Talking About?’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: When I was small, we lived above my father’s office in Bed-Stuy. My father said he would spot me and my mother out the window and wonder, “What could those two be talking about?” Since I could speak, I talked. And my mother listened. When the hospice nurse said, “It will be soon,” I wasn’t surprised. Earlier that day, my mother told me, “JoAnn, I just can’t listen to you anymore.” She always listened to me. Five years after her passing, I still haven’t found someone who makes me feel fully heard. Maybe Mom set the bar too high. — JoAnn Leah Rock
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York City to Pay $92.5 Million to Improperly Detained Immigrants
description: The city was accused of unlawfully holding more than 20,000 people beyond their scheduled release dates between 1997 and 2012 to comply with ICE detainer requests.
content: For years, federal immigration agents had a reliable place to find undocumented immigrants they wanted to deport: New York City jails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: The Economy Is Finally Stable. Is That About to Change?
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s proposals on tariffs, immigration, taxes and deregulation may have far-reaching and contradictory effects, adding uncertainty to forecasts.
content: After five years of uncertainty and turmoil, the U.S. economy is ending 2024 in arguably its most stable condition since the start of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold
title: New Watchdog Group Seeks Records About Efficiency Department’s Talks With Agencies
description: State Democracy Defenders Fund, founded by a former ethics official from the Obama Administration, asked 16 federal agencies if they had heard from Elon Musk’s budget-cutting group.
content: A watchdog nonprofit said Wednesday that it was asking 16 federal agencies to detail any interactions they have had with Elon Musk’s new budget-cutting effort, the Department of Government Efficiency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: This Book Tour Comes With a Side of Fried Rice
description: Curtis Chin’s memoir, “Everything I Learned, I Learned in a Chinese Restaurant,” celebrates the cuisine and community of his youth. Now he’s paying it forward.
content: As Curtis Chin got ready to talk about his memoir, “Everything I Learned, I Learned in a Chinese Restaurant,” waiters in powder blue jackets delivered steaming platters of lo mein and bok choy to tables full of readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should Schools Spy on Student Devices to Prevent Self-Harm?
description: New technology alerts schools when students type words related to suicide. Should all schools use it? Or is it an invasion of privacy?
content: From 2014 to 2018, Neosho High School in southwestern Missouri, pictured above, had eight student suicides, an alarming number in a district of just under 5,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: A Ten Commandments Tablet Sells for More Than $5 Million at Auction
description: Sotheby’s called the stone the world’s oldest inscribed with the Ten Commandments, but some experts had raised questions about its provenance and authenticity.
content: A stone tablet that was described by Sotheby’s as the oldest in the world inscribed with the Ten Commandments sold on Wednesday for just over $5 million to an anonymous buyer who plans to donate it to an Israeli institution, the auction house said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,279
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Dec. 19, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Prisoner’s Self-Portraits of C.I.A. Torture Surface From Sealed Court Record
description: “This is what his nightmares are all about,” said a lawyer for a now-confessed war criminal who spent years at Guantánamo Bay.
content: Alone in his cell with only dark thoughts of desperate times, the prisoner put pencil to paper and drew detailed portraits of how American agents tortured him 20 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Defense Bill Orders Military to Take New Action on Brain Injury
description: Mandates in the annual appropriations act, passed on Wednesday, call for the Pentagon to track and mitigate risks to troops’ brains from firing their own weapons.
content: Congress passed a sweeping new set of mandates on brain safety in the military Wednesday, requiring the Pentagon to set new safety limits for troops’ blast exposure, track and report exposures throughout their careers, modify existing weapons to reduce the danger and, for the first time, take brain safety into account when designing new weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: Bat Feces Used to Fertilize Cannabis Is Linked to 2 Deaths
description: Two men in Rochester, N.Y., died after being infected with a rare fungus found in bat feces, which is sometimes used as fertilizer, researchers wrote in a medical journal.
content: Two men died after they contracted a rare fungal infection from exposure to bat feces, also known as guano, that they were using to grow cannabis plants, according to a report published in a medical journal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: A 7-Eleven Heir’s $50 Billion Fight to Keep the Company in the Family
description: A battle for control of the chain shows how traditional business models embraced by family owners are clashing with a more shareholder-centric approach.
content: Junro Ito flew to California this year on a mission: The billionaire executive at Seven & i Holdings, the Japanese parent company of 7-Eleven, felt the company had lost its way. He wanted to revive the culture fostered by his father, the company’s founder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Police Can Seize £2 Million From Andrew Tate Accounts, U.K. Court Rules
description: The online influencer has bragged about refusing to pay taxes. A London court found that he and his brother had not paid taxes on more than £21 million in business revenue.
content: A London court ruled on Wednesday that the police in Britain can seize more than 2 million pounds, about $2.5 million, from bank accounts associated with Andrew Tate, the misogynistic online influencer who has bragged about evading taxes in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen and Arlette Bashizi
title: Tiny Coffins: Measles Is Killing Thousands of Children in Congo
description: Problems with getting vaccines to families have left many children unvaccinated and in danger of contracting the virus.
content: Werra Maulu Botey could not bear to close his daughter’s coffin. Waiting to bury her, he slid the rough wooden lid back, again and again, to adjust her small head and smooth the cloth that cradled it away from her cheeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Fed Cut Rates and Signaled a Long Fight Against Inflation
description: Also, California declared an emergency over bird flu. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Federal Reserve officials made their third and final rate cut of 2024 today, reducing borrowing costs by a quarter of a percentage point. They also shook up financial markets by forecasting notably higher inflation and two fewer rate cuts in 2025 than they had previously expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Megan Thee Stallion Seeks Restraining Order Against Tory Lanez
description: Her lawyers said Mr. Lanez had facilitated a “campaign of harassment” from prison, where he is serving a 10-year sentence after being convicted of shooting her.
content: Megan Thee Stallion has asked a court in Los Angeles to issue a restraining order against the rapper Tory Lanez, who is currently in prison serving a 10-year sentence for shooting her in 2020. Her lawyers said he had been waging a “campaign of harassment” against her from behind bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Stocks Plunge as Fed Forecasts Fewer Rate Cuts Next Year
description: The Federal Reserve cut rates for a third time this year, but investors shuddered at revised forecasts suggesting only two cuts in 2025.
content: Stocks slumped, the dollar soared and the cost of borrowing money rose on Wednesday, as the Fed dialed down expectations for interest rate cuts next year given the continued strength of the U.S. economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justices to Hear Case on South Carolina’s Bid to Defund Planned Parenthood
description: The issue in the case is whether Medicaid beneficiaries may sue under a law that lets them choose care from any provider qualified to perform the required services.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Wednesday to consider whether South Carolina may eliminate Medicaid funding for any medical services offered by Planned Parenthood because it performs abortions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Truly, the Best Mashed Potatoes I’ve Ever Had
description: Potatoes and olive oil come together in this simple yet extraordinary dish.
content: After his first marriage ended, the chef Nick Anderer vowed to himself that he would never marry again. But “I’m a hopeless romantic,” he said one Thursday morning at his West Village restaurant, Anton’s, where he showed me how he makes his olive-oil mashed potatoes. Whenever I tell people I like to eat those Anton’s potatoes for dinner with a glass of wine and a good book, I have to repeat myself to emphasize: I like to eat just those potatoes for dinner. They are, truly, the best mashed potatoes I’ve ever had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: The Trocks Fill Out the Laughs With Dancing Chops
description: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo opens its season at the Joyce Theater with its vintage, vampiric “Giselle” and a new take on Balanchine.
content: Arlene Croce, the great American dance critic who wrote for The New Yorker from 1973 to 1996, died on Monday morning, the day before Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo lifted the curtain on its December season at the Joyce Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Supreme Court Fast-Tracks TikTok Case in Face of Jan. 19 Deadline
description: The company and its Chinese parent invoked the First Amendment in urging the justices to step in before a deadline to sell or be shut down.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Wednesday to hear TikTok’s challenge to a law that could ban its U.S. operations, putting the case on an exceptionally fast track that will culminate in oral arguments next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Robert Draper
title: House Panel Is Said to Have Voted to Release the Gaetz Report
description: Lawmakers agreed the report would come out after the House has completed legislative business for the year and once they have left Washington to return to their districts.
content: The House Ethics Committee secretly voted this month to release an investigative report into the conduct of former Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: Back-to-Back-to-Back Atmospheric Rivers Are Expected to Soak the West Coast
description: A run of storms is moving through the Pacific Northwest and Northern California over the next week.
content: A barrage of storms known as atmospheric rivers is expected to soak the West Coast over the next eight to 10 days, raising the risk of flooding, power outages and holiday travel disruptions leading up to Christmas in a region that has already experienced significant weather activity this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: Two Mountains, Two Countries, a Cross- Border Skiing Adventure
description: On a ‘two-nation ski vacation,’ a writer samples Idaho’s Schweitzer and Red Mountain, in British Columbia, two less-crowded resorts with miles of terrain to explore.
content: My friend Michelle and I took turns following each other as we skied through stands of snow- and rime-coated subalpine fir. It had been three days since the last snowfall, but on this frigid January day at Schweitzer, in Idaho’s panhandle, we still found soft, untracked powder. It was delightful, but not a surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Surveilling Speech Won’t Increase Birthrates
description: It’s easier for governments to restrict freedom of expression than it is to fix material conditions.
content: President Vladimir Putin of Russia recently signed a bill into law that will fine anyone who is promoting “child-free propaganda.” Meant both to shore up “traditional values” and to increase Russia’s tanking birthrate, it stipulates that any individual found to be disseminating such “propaganda” may be subject to fines of up to about $4,000; considering the average monthly Russian salary as of 2023 was around $800, that’s a frightening potential penalty. Companies could be fined up to about $50,000. This law joins other Russian legislation that attaches fines to expressions of support for the “international L.G.B.T. social movement,” such as posting a rainbow flag online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Killing of Russian General Sends a Message, but Doesn’t Change the War
description: Ukraine’s forces are steadily losing ground on the battlefield. The assassination of a top general in Moscow won’t improve their war effort, analysts and Western officials say.
content: Ukraine’s brazen assassination of a Russian general on a Moscow street this week was a triumph for Ukraine’s intelligence services, showcasing a decade’s worth of investment in developing the skills, technology and ingenuity needed to operate successfully behind enemy lines in wartime.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 18, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 18, 2024.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the atrocities at Syrian prisons under Bashar al-Assad’s government misstated the number of years the Assad family was in power. It was roughly 53 years, not 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Sir Lady Java, ’60s Drag Star Who Challenged the Law, Dies
description: Long before the term “drag queen” was widely used, her act was popular in the Black entertainment world but barred under a Los Angeles municipal code.
content: At first, it was lonely being Sir Lady Java.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Art of the Gift: Roz Chast
description: The award-winning cartoonist, who admits to having a “very fraught” relationship with gift-giving, still loves handmade gifts from her children.
content: Roz Chast, 70, is a writer and cartoonist best known for more than four decades of output at The New Yorker. Her latest book, “I Must Be Dreaming,” was published last year. This October, she received a National Humanities Medal for her contributions to cartooning. She lives in Ridgefield, Conn. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Perfect Latkes, However You Like Them
description: My five-star latkes fry up either thin and crunchy, flecked with golden, crackling strands, or chubby and nubby, with soft, fluffy centers.
content: Hanukkah starts on Christmas Day this year, which, for families celebrating both, makes for one pretty busy Wednesday. But I can’t wait to wake up and open presents in the morning next to the tree … and then open more presents in the evening next to the menorah. When it comes to holiday cheer, more is more!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
title: Trump Criticizes Spending Deal, Pushing Congress Toward a Shutdown
description: The president-elect weighed in against the huge spending package after Elon Musk had spent the day warning Republicans not to support it. The blowup left the compromise on life support.
content: A bipartisan spending deal to avert a shutdown was on life support on Wednesday after President-elect Donald J. Trump condemned it, leaving lawmakers without a strategy to fund the government past a Friday night deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: California Declares an Emergency Over Bird Flu in Cattle
description: Officials have discovered the virus in 645 dairy herds, more than in any other state so far.
content: In a stark acknowledgment of the increasing seriousness of bird flu’s spread, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California declared on Wednesday that the outbreak of infections among the state’s dairy cattle constituted an emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Giving Pledge Group, Led by Gates and Buffett, Removes Billionaire Accused of Fraud
description: Arif Naqvi, founder of the Abraaj Group, a Dubai-based private equity firm that collapsed in 2018, was indicted by U.S. prosecutors in 2019.
content: A former private-equity tycoon in the Middle East has been ousted from the high-profile philanthropy group made up of some of the world’s wealthiest people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Ben Casselman, Edgar Sandoval, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Fed Expected to Cut Rates, and C.E.O. Shooting Suspect Branded Terrorist
description: Plus, a beefy new skin care trend.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Dana Rubinstein and Michael Rothfeld
title: $100,000 Loan for Porsche at Center of Charges Against Former Adams Aide
description: Ingrid Lewis-Martin, her son, and two businessmen were expected to be arraigned on bribery charges connected to the loan for Lewis-Martin’s son.
content: Ingrid Lewis-Martin, the former chief adviser to Mayor Eric Adams, is expected to surrender on Thursday on bribery charges involving two businessmen who gave her son a $100,000 loan to buy a Porsche, several people with knowledge of the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: A Woman on Our Girls’ Trip Has Grown Snarky. Can We Stop Inviting Her?
description: Her bitter comments and antisocial behavior may spring from discomfort around her high-achieving friends, but that doesn’t make her any easier to deal with.
content: I go on an annual trip with a group of women I’ve known for 20 years. It’s a special getaway. But one of the women has become increasingly negative: She makes judgmental comments about the rest of us and browses social media during meals. In fairness, her life is very different from ours: She is the only one of us who doesn’t have children or a thriving career. A few years ago, one of us talked to her privately about our impression that she wasn’t having a good time. She expressed surprise, but then confessed that she felt self-conscious about contributing to group conversations. We never exclude her, so that means that someone has to talk to her one on one at the expense of participating in group conversations. And the snarky comments continue. Do we have to keep inviting her?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Youth Climate Activists Get Major Win in Montana Supreme Court
description: The court agreed that the state’s energy policies violated Montanans’ constitutional right to a clean environment.
content: The Montana Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld a landmark victory for youth climate activists, affirming a decision by a lower court last year that the state’s energy policies violated their constitutional rights to a clean environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: U.S. Agrees to Pay $116 Million to Settle Sexual Abuse Claims at California Prison
description: Lawyers for the victims said it was the largest deal of its kind reached with the federal Bureau of Prisons.
content: The federal government agreed on Tuesday to pay about $116 million to settle lawsuits by 103 women who said they had been sexually abused while in custody at a now-shuttered women’s prison in Northern California where such claims were rampant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Find Your Way Around That Updated Photos App
description: Redesigned interfaces, new features and artificial intelligence are meant to enhance the experience, even if the changes can be confusing at first.
content: Apple’s fall overhaul of its Photos app — publicized by the company as its “biggest redesign ever” — gave the software a fresh look and new methods for managing your portable picture library on the iPhone and iPad. However, not everyone was a fan, as the new design retired familiar navigational icons in favor of a “unified” view that put almost everything on one screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Done With Never Trump
description: There’s plenty to dislike and fear about Trump, but Never Trumpers overstated our case, defeating our purpose.
content: It’s been more than nine years since I first denounced Donald Trump as a “loudmouth vulgarian appealing to quieter vulgarians.” I’ve called myself a Never Trump conservative ever since, even when I agreed with his policies from time to time. I also opposed him throughout his run this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How Elon Musk and Taylor Swift Can Resolve U.S.-China Relations
description: Trump will face a new China this time, one whose advanced manufacturing muscles have exploded in size, sophistication and quantity.
content: I just spent a week in Beijing and Shanghai, meeting with Chinese officials, economists and entrepreneurs, and let me get right to the point: While we were sleeping China took a great leap forward in high-tech manufacturing of everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson, Kaleigh Rogers and Steven Lee Myers
title: These Voters Want to ‘Stop the Steal.’ Top Democrats Aren’t Interested.
description: A movement by some Democratic voters to investigate the results of the 2024 presidential election mirrors a push by Republicans in 2020. But it’s struggling.
content: The 2024 presidential election has set off a new wave of election denialism online — only this time, it is coming from voters on the left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: What Is a New York Movie? In 2024, the Definition Changed.
description: Whether it was “A Complete Unknown” with 1960s Greenwich Village or “Anora” with present-day Brooklyn, filmmakers put new frames around the city.
content: When I was a teenager, the New York City I saw in the movies seemed attainable, the sort of place to bring big ambitions and a few suitcases. These films weren’t “The Warriors” or “Escape From New York” or anything directed by Martin Scorsese. Instead they starred plucky heroines living on tree-lined streets who donned heels and pencil skirts for their magazine jobs. I envied the dinner parties in creaky, book-filled homes, the pastrami on rye downtown, the piles of books characters clutched alongside rumpled copies of a certain New York newspaper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
title: New Battles Threaten Kurdish-Turkish Truce in Northern Syria
description: U.S.-backed, Kurdish-led forces say they have come under fresh attack in several places by a Turkish-backed militia, even as Washington seeks a lasting cease-fire.
content: Battles between Kurdish and Turkish-backed fighters in northern Syria threatened on Wednesday to upend already shaky cease-fire agreements and stymie American attempts to contain escalating violence just as the country’s 13-year civil war is ending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Pearson
title: In Search of Sauna Nirvana Around Lake Superior
description: On a 750-mile road trip through the heart of sauna culture in the United States, a writer searches for the perfect combination of steam, heat and cold.
content: It is never a good idea to pause between a 194-degree sauna and the mind-bending frigidity of Lake Superior in February. As sweat cools on skin, the rational mind kicks in. Why submit the body to such unrelenting shock, it asks. I know this voice well. Yet here I am, on a cobblestone beach in Grand Marais, Minn., with precious heat steaming off my head, pausing to contemplate the wave-sculpted ice that appears to be growing toward the sky like stalagmites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Think You’re High Class? How Do You Feel About Twice-Baked Potatoes?
description: By weighing in on 35 meal options, a popular online quiz claims it can determine your social standing. It might not be so simple.
content: When, after you have cleaned out your sock drawer and stopped doomscrolling for sanity’s sake in the idle space between 3 and 4 a.m., sleep still refuses to come, there remains one option. There is the ubiquitous personality quiz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Ivor Prickett
title: Al-Assad’s Soldiers Hope for Amnesty. First, They Have to Take a Number.
description: Syria’s new rulers say they will spare conscripts of Bashar al-Assad and pursue those who oversaw his regime’s abuses. Hundreds are lining up to learn which promise applies to them.
content: Hundreds of soldiers and police officers converged this week on a former security compound in the western Syrian city of Latakia, heeding the call of the country’s new rulers to relinquish their ties to the ousted regime of President Bashar al-Assad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Russia Detains a Man It Says Killed a General on Ukraine’s Orders
description: The Russian prosecutor’s office said the suspect, a 29-year-old citizen of Uzbekistan, confessed to planting the bomb on the orders of Ukrainian agents.
content: The Russian authorities said on Wednesday that they had detained a suspect in the killing of a senior military officer, Lt. Gen. Igor Kirillov, a major development in the most prominent political assassination case in the country since the start of the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azam Ahmed and Bryan Denton
title: The Once Booming Drug Town Going Bust Under Taliban Rule
description: Funding its war against the United States, the Taliban reaped millions from boom towns trading opium, heroin and meth. Victorious, the group crushed the trade, leaving ghost towns in its wake.
content: An oasis stretched far into the desert, a vast sea of emerald stalks and scarlet poppy flowers that grew to the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Marder
title: A 20-Minute Exercise Band Workout to Build Strength
description: If you are short on time and space, here is a cheap, effective way to get stronger.
content: A set of resistance bands may be the perfect workout gear. They’re cheaper than a single kettlebell and can slip into a suitcase pocket. You can roll your desk chair across the room, grab a set of bands and knock out a short set between meetings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: The Wrath of Trump: House Republicans Map a Case Against Liz Cheney
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has never been shy about his desire to see his enemies punished. But he often shows a measure of caution about taking credit for potential prosecutions himself.
content: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Donald Trump and the presidential transition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Year in Pictures 2024: Far From Ordinary
description: Photographers captured historic moments of war, grief and wonder that defined the year.
content: Photographers captured historic moments of war, grief and wonder that defined the year.

title: For a Desperate Few, a Hectic Escape From Gaza
description: The war is nearly impossible to flee — except for a small number of sick and wounded who are offered a dramatic path to safety.

description: The year brought not only an increase in volume, but severe storms in the U.S. also caused $46 billion in damage, among the highest costs on record.
content: The year brought not only an increase in volume, but severe storms in the U.S. also caused $46 billion in damage, among the highest costs on record.

description: Without insurance, it’s impossible to get a mortgage; without a mortgage, most Americans can’t buy a home.

title: Syria’s First Domestic Flight Since the Assad Regime Fell Takes Off
description: The Damascus International Airport reopened on Wednesday with a domestic flight to Aleppo, signaling that Syria’s new rulers are confident in their ability to govern after the end of the Assad family’s rule.
content: The Damascus International Airport reopened on Wednesday with a domestic flight to Aleppo, signaling that Syria’s new rulers are confident in their ability to govern after the end of the Assad family’s rule.

title: The Federal Reserve Cuts Interest Rates By a Quarter Percentage Point
description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, announced the central bank’s final interest rate cut for the year and suggested only two more reductions in 2025.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, announced the central bank’s final interest rate cut for the year and suggested only two more reductions in 2025.

author: By Neil Collier, Alex Pena, Chevaz Clarke and Mark Boyer
title: They Fought for Assad in Syria. Now They’re Handing in Their Guns.
description: Across Syria, soldiers tied to the former Assad regime are surrendering their weapons to the interim government. The New York Times spoke to some of these men in Latakia, as they face a new and uncertain future as civilians.
content: Across Syria, soldiers tied to the former Assad regime are surrendering their weapons to the interim government. The New York Times spoke to some of these men in Latakia, as they face a new and uncertain future as civilians.

title: Dashcam Video Shows Honolulu Plane Crash
description: A small plane crashed near the Daniel K. Inouye International Airport in Honolulu, killing two people, officials said.
